Comment: Of course ideologues want to swap ideologues they like for ideologues they don't like. Here's the thing: majorities of Americans are suspicious of ideologues of *any* stripe. They like people running governmental apparatuses (pretty sure that's not a word) to be competent, communicative, & accountable. "charisma" can be a nice to have, but you should be wary of it.  DeToqueville understood that, for reasons it takes book-length explanations to address, our way of choosing officials favors the stupid & the shrill in the moment over what we'd prefer day-to-day. To get the latter, we have to be smart, patient, flexible, *and* lucky. Imagining we just need to hack at it like "the other guys" is just wrong.

Comment: You realize that Democrats are a center/center-right party, right? Harris lost because Biden dropped out way too late, denying Democrats the ability to have a proper primary. Harris also didn't run a great campaign - she ignored progressives in favor of Liz Cheney.    Her campaign advisors should never work politics again.   Dems lost because they lost their way to try to appease independents and center-right voters while shouting down the left. They wrongly thought that there was a large Republican voting bloc who was so desperate to get away from Trump that they would happily vote for a centrist Democrat. Maybe there were a few, but definitely not enough to swing the election. (And not considering any Musk shenanigans)   Now there is no true progressive party, so people are just not voting. They lost their identity because they're trying too hard to be Republican-lite on all matters (economy, immigration, criminal justice). They also played with fire (Roe v Wade) and didn't codify it when they had the chance because it was their fundraising cash cow.   It's not that people voted for Trump, it's that they just didn't vote which gave the election to Trump. Blame the voters all you want, but that's the reality when you go against party principles.   People stopped voting because they're tired of the status quo. They want change and a younger group of representatives will give them that.

Comment: > It doesn’t matter. If he’s status quo, he’s part of the problem.   It's crazy that you guys just openly admit to having no actual goals or intentions to defeat Republicans. Your entire ideology is just a dog chasing a car.  When Ken Martin took over the Minnesota Democratic Party it was broke and had just lost the state legislature to the Republicans. Under his leadership Democrats took back power, MN was the only Midwest swing state to never vote for Trump and they passed one of the most progressive legislative agendas in the entire country:  > Minnesota now offers 12 weeks of paid family and medical leave, the opportunity for any resident to buy into Medicaid, free public college tuition for low- and middle-income families, a new child tax credit for those families, free breakfast and lunch for all public school students, driver’s licenses for all residents regardless of their immigration status, and stronger protections for workers seeking to unionize. >  > Middle-class seniors will no longer have to pay state income taxes on Social Security benefits. A law immediately restoring the voting rights of felons who have completed their prison sentences expanded the franchise to 55,000 more people.  Recreational marijuana is legal. A new state law protects abortion rights. A “trans refuge” law shields transgender children who travel to Minnesota for medical transitions from legal repercussions in their home states. And Minnesota has set a goal of moving to 100% carbon-free energy by 2040.  Ken Martin is exactly the type of person you put in charge if you want the party to rebound.
